name: Shrubs, Trees, and Flowers
description:
Gardening or cultivation [is] a practice which, engaged in with an appropriate sensibility … embodies more saliently than any other practice the truth of the relation between human beings, their world, and the 'ground' from which the 'gift' of this world comes. (David E. Cooper, A Philosophy of Gardens | pp. 160-61)


I often spend time walking around the neighborhood with my daughter. She usually picks up leaves or flowers that are scattered in front of the neighbors' houses. Sometimes, I also ask permission to pick some flowers from them.

This habit raises many questions in my head. Why did they build a garden? What kind of considerations is in determining suitable plants in their yard? What does the garden mean to them and their families?

I think the garden can represent many things, ranging from economic conditions, the arena of contemplation, or the development of popular culture.
